description.text: This is a laser holder for the JTech Phototonics 2.8w laser. Before I simply used tape to attach it to the side of the extruder body, now it attaches onto the screw tops, and has a screw attached through it in order to quickly adjust z-height of the laser for better focus

print both at medium print settings (like .2 layer height at 40mm/s) should be fine quality, left room in the back for heat to easily escape.
attach 2 pieces together with 3/16 threaded rod (or whatever size you have) and have 2 bolts containing bottom piece and 1 bolt on top of the top piece to allow for easy adjustment (see images).

description.text: There are many others, but I wanted a minimal and nice design that does not protrude outside of the reel (so you can stack them without launching an edge clip). Use the two last loops of the filament. Insert the first loop in the clip, pull the end of the filament tight and then insert the second loop in the clip. It works because the two loops want to go straight and work against each other. The pictures are of 3mm filament. I haven't tested the 1,75mm one, but another maker did (see Makes), and says it works as well. Consider printing it 1-2% smaller when your filament is relatively thin or oily. If you make one, please share the results! Per request I've made a new version (V2) with longer and higher ducts. Also while I was at it, I made a version with ribs to better grapple the filament (RibbedForYourPleasure-V2). I tested the 3mm ribbed version, and it works extremely well. Principle inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:635200

Two 3D parts which transform a 12V Lead-acid battery to a portable power station. Gives 12V and USB 5V. Using a selfie stick as an handle. At the end of the stick I added a 4W COB LED chip which makes it a convenient light pole for camping. one can attach: lights, phone charging, air pump (for inflatable mattress) and much more. Improvements that should be made:
Add the hole for 12V socket
Add the hole for power switch
Add the support for USB transformer from the bottom side
Add two metal flat springs as battery contacts.
Enjoy it!

comments.text: I have one on the printer now, will post pics after it is complete. This is pretty close to what I was actually looking for, and was wondering if you could remix it a little? I would love to get one of these with the holes for a power switch, and space for a fuse, and to top it all off... anderson power poles!

This is the final version of the I-Hacked.com badge (art by surbo).  This badge is modified slightly from the original design to house a bicolor LED (hevnsnt's awesome idea, not mine!) and to allow the battery tray to stay in place without any additional hardware (so it can be attached to other badges,  etc.).
The battery tray also features a nice lip so the CR2025 wonâ€™t just fall out when you pull out the tray.  This was done primarily to convince badge recipients that the battery only went in one way, as the bicolor LED was to remain an "undocumented feature".  All badges had red/blue LEDs and started off red, but if you flipped the entire tray over and re-inserted it youâ€™d have a blue badge.  As many of you probably know, blues and reds donâ€™t generally get along very wellâ€¦

This badge is constructed in a very similar fashion to the first prototype (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:863), so use that as a basic guide. Iâ€™ll just cover the major changes here, but note that construction on this version is slightly more involved. The middle bridging section on this badge has a couple protruding â€œnubsâ€ that grab on to the battery door when inserted. This means that the â€œarmsâ€ of this middle section that the nubs are on must be allowed to move. This is why thereâ€™s an etched out area on the middle bridging section in this version. This etched channel is meant to stop the acrylic glue from wicking up the entire arm and gluing it permanently in place. The etched side of the bridging section must face toward the surface youâ€™re gluing when attaching this piece to the back of the badge for this to work. You donâ€™t necessarily have to take the same precaution when attaching the top piece because you can easily see where the glue is wicking to and only glue the lower section. Acrylic isnâ€™t ideal for these kinds of snap together pieces, as itâ€™s relatively brittle, but the tags only needed to last a couple days. Now to the matter of the getting the bicolor LED to work. Just having the correct lead touching the side of the battery was enough to get the prototype working, but to get the bicolor LED to work you need to have one lead of the LED rest on top of the battery and one rest below it. This will allow you to switch the polarity, and thus the color of the LED, by flipping the battery over. Unfortunately, a CR2025 cell is too thick to be used in this configuration so youâ€™ve got to create a shallow depression for one of the LED leads to lay in on the back piece by raster etching a bit of the plastic away. Make sure this depression is facing toward the inside of the badge when assembling! When inserting the LED, ensure that the lower LED lead is in this depression, and when inserting the battery, take care not to catch the leads on the edge of the battery and bend them up! As with the previous version, you can get the LED out after the badge is assembled, but itâ€™s much easier to try and get it right the first time. If youâ€™re not using a bicolor LED, just use the instructions from the previous version for, bending/inserting the LED. Lastly, the lip added to the battery tray is something you can only do if youâ€™ve got direct access to a laser cutter. To form the lip, I raster etch the plastic away in multiple passes until I reach the depth I want (Iâ€™ve described this in a little more detail here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:773)). I use a pair of digital calipers to verify that Iâ€™ve got the depth I want before finally cutting out the pieces. I may revisit this project once our space gets a MakerBot up and running, as a lot of the parts for this project would probably be more easily constructed with a 3D printer and I could use some more ideal materials :)

title: Robox 1kg spool using acrylic for the sides

description.text:
To speed up making spools, I decided to use Dremel with circular
attachment to cut 2 pcs. of acrylic instead of printing those wings. 28/07/2015 - updated hub to ver 0.6

Use the jig to drill 3.2mm(1/8") hole in the center and 3x 3mm holes (with countersink) on the acrylic sheet. Then use the jig to adjust the circular attachment to cut the outter circle then inner circle.

title: Trapezoid Screw Thread Module: Extrude-Transform Polygons

description.text: JelleAtProtospace pointed out that trapezoid screw thread are useful as well, e.g. to make a drivenut for the leadscrew threaded rods used in many CNC machines. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trapezoidal_thread_forms That sounded like a valuable and fairly simple modification, but I wasn't looking forward to modifying the polyhedron command at the heart of the module (adding each new vertex means adding several triangles and making sure they have the right winding order), but like anything else, you get used to it with practice and it really wasn't that bad. It allows you to generate trapezoid screw threads that follow any set of equations you care to provide them, some of which will have more practical application that others. Some of these even look like they might make serviceable springs. Again, because it generates the triangles directly via the polyhedron command, it's fast and lightweight.

This is actually pretty clean code, feel free to take a look. Also, since it compiles fast, experiments are easy! GitHub repository:
github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/ExtrudePolygon If there is enough interest, I could make a library version?

description.text:
A version of the model "To revive a unicorn". This is meant to print with a classical wall mount attached on the back of the trophy. The model is part of a project which explore 3D-printings ability to make art accessible to everyone, everywhere and become an everyday-experience,
as well as its capability to let people rework and remix art and find new purposes and contexts for art pieces. As part of the project I want to encourage you and everyone else to use this model in whatever way you can imagine - Remix it, hack it or just print it and use it as it is, for what you want. And I will highly appreciate you sharing photos, models and other documentation of what you might do whith it, both here and and on Instagram with the hastag #toreviveaunicorn. Thanks :)

author: aschermerhorn

description.text: I had a wonderful opportunity to show my son's 2nd grade class about additive manufacturing and 3D printing.  I was invited to show the class my 3D printer during a week the kids were learning about inventing and product development.  I used my wedding ring as an example of an item that could be improved and made into something that looked different or suited a different need.  I told the class that I always wanted a thinner, less bulky version of my wedding ring, but before I go to a jeweler, it would be nice to make an inexpensive version and prototype it before I pay to have it made.  I designed the ring right before their eyes in 3D CAD, then sliced it and printed.  It was wonderul to see the kids' reaction and hear all of their inquisitive questions about the process.  Great fun was had on my part!
Print the ring flat on your print bed and no support will be needed.

In this project, students will learn and apply basic programming skills with the OpenSCAD language to style and customize a nametag. Visually, OpenSCAD is different from other types of 3D modeling programs. It’s a simple declarative computer language that was built specifically for designing 3D printable models. By modifying existing OpenSCAD code for a wavy nametag, students will explore parameters, dimensions, “for” loops, translations, and boolean operations.
CCSS

Students will learn how to write basic code to generate objects with the OpenSCAD language. Once comfortable, they’ll explore a sample coding project that prompts them to discover how changing different variables affects their 3D model. Finally, they’ll add their own unique variables and functions to further customize a nametag. This project, found in MakerBot in The Classroom (http://www.makerbot.com/education), focuses on creating a parametric model using the program OpenSCAD. You can download OpenSCAD from http://openscad.org/ or use it online from http://openscad.net/. CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSF.TF.B.5
Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline. CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RST.11-12.7: Integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., quantitative data, video, multimedia) in order to address a question or solve a problem. CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSF.IF.C.7
Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.

The entire lesson is laid out with pictures in the .PDF downloadable in the Thing Files. Step 1: Making a Parametric nametag with existing code
  • Try to figure out what the code is doing
  • Modify text and font parameters
  • Adjust dimensions to match the text
  • Style the wave of the nametag border
  • Create a new parameter for the text height
  • Create a new parameter for character spacing
  • Output an STL mesh for 3D printing
    • Step 2: Write OpenSCAD code from scratch to design a model
  • Plan, Think, and Code
  • Try new things
  • Export, print, test, repeat

• Code
  • Translation
  • openscad
  • modifying parameters
  • measuring
  • basic code
  • writing code
• 1-2 class periods - Print time: 20-35 minutes per nametag

To prepare for this lesson you will need the following supplies:
  • Chromebook or computer per student
  • Openscad.org or openscad.net open or installed
  • openscad_project.pdf handout (in Thing Files)
  • MakerBot_NametagCode_Project.scad downloaded (in Thing Files)

• What are the benefits of a parametric design?
  • How do you generate basic shapes with code?
  • Why is it important to use variables in OpenSCAD code?
  • What are examples of parameters you might change when designing an object?
  • What do you need to change or add to your OpenSCAD file to allow it to be used in Customizer?
Reimann Sum - http://mathworld.wolfram.com/RiemannSum.html
Extension Activity

description.header: Modify OpenSCAD code for thingiverse customizer
description.text:
• Review documentation on making a customizable thing at http://customizer.makerbot.com/docs.
  • Download code file MakerBot_NametagCode_Project.scad from the MakerBot Learning account on Thingiverse.
  • Compare with the same OpenSCAD code used in the Thingiverse Customizer (select 4. View Source from the lower right corner of the Customizer at the MakerBot Learning account).
  • Make modifications as you explore.

description.header: Explore the trigonometry used in the nametag
description.text:
• Have precalculus students investigate the function used in the wavy border design of the nametags:
    • function f(x) =
    2base +
    0.5    (height - 2base)
    (cos(frequencyx360/(steps-1)) + 1);
  • In particular, what does each of the components of this function do to change the shape of the wave? Consider amplitude, frequency, and transformations. What would happen if the cosine function were replaced with the sine function? What other functions would make good nametag borders?
  • Change and consider what amplitude, frequency, and transformations are doing.
  • Try changing the cosine function to sine. What happens?
  • Explore other functions that could affect the border.

• The wave shape on the border of the nametag design is actually a simple Riemann sum approximation of the area under the graph of the function f(x) on an interval. Here’s the code that produces the steps of the wave.
    • for( i = [0:steps-1] ){
    translate([ i*(length/steps), 0, 0 ])
    cube([ length/steps, width, f(i) ]);
  • Look at a small number of steps to get an idea of what is happening. What type of Riemann sum is being constructed?
  • Something subtle is happening with the steps-1 part of the function definition. Why is that part of the code here and what does it do for the design? Replace steps-1 with a value (try 4, 8, etc.) and note what happens. What does it mean about the interval being used for the Riemann sum?

description.text:
Cho Oyu, 6th highest mountain in the world, and the Ngozumpa glacier below it. Model has 4 quadrants (NW, NE, SW, SE) including Cho Oyu and the north end of Ngozumpa (NW), the southern end of Ngozumpa (SW), and two quadrants to the east including Mt. Everest (NE and SE). I printed the NW and SW quadrants for a friend's expedition to study the glacier.
  • UPDATE: See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16851 for instructions on making your own.
  • Now available at Github: https://github.com/bld/Cho-Oyu-and-Ngozumpa-Glacier

The models were produced using Shuttle Radar Topography Mission 90-m resolution data. At a later time, I will post the recipe for doing this using data from anywhere. For the time being, I am posting Blender models - as displacement maps and as meshes - as well as the STL files. STL files are scaled for printing on a Makerbot Cupcake CNC with recessed screws.
I used all open source tools:
  • Geospatial Data Abstraction Library (GDAL) to convert SRTM HGT files to GEOTIFF
  • GIMP to crop the GEOTIFFs
  • Blender to produce displacement maps from the GEOTIFFS and meshes
  • Meshlab to close the holes
    I found that the default scale of the Blender displacement maps was too flat. I did a test print and used calipers to get the scale right. Each pixel in X/Y is 90-m. To get the vertical relief correct, I measured the height of known parts of the map (summit of Cho Oyu and a nearby valley) and compared this to terrain maps in Google maps and the width of the model (200 pixels multiplied by 90m).

title: moi fuau (an object sung into existence)

description.text:
In Alien Dreamtime, Mr. T. M. sez:
"And what they were doing, was they were making objects come into existence by singing them into existence. Objects which looked like FabergÃ© eggs from Mars morphing themselves with Mandaean alphabetical structures. They looked like the concrescence of linguistic intentionality put through a kind of hyper-dimensional transform into three-dimensional space. And these little machines offered themselves to me. And I realized when I looked at them that if I could bring just one of these little trinkets back, nothing would ever be quite the same again...interrupted me and said, "Don't think about it. Don't think about who we are... Think about doing what we're doing. Do it! Do it! DO IT NOW!!!"" Later on there is a bit of glossolalia which is transcribed here:
http://www.lycaeum.org/~sputnik/mckenna/alien.html as "moi phoi" But sounds like "moi fuau" when listened on youtube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DcY1NX6ZScc So why not do what what Mr. McKenna's "instructors suggest? The "moi fuau" sounds like an interruption in the glossolalia. I sampled that and generated a stack of images which I (very poorly) converted into an .stl file

These are quite cheap , check amazon or PE.

author: PCFlyer

title: Arduino Materia 101 - Low profile glass plate clips

description.text:
After adding the extruder fan duct to my Arduino Materia 101 (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:867746), I felt the need to replace the clips that came with my printer with clips having a lower profile, in order not to interfere with the extruder or the fan duct in large prints. The clips are sized for a glass plate with blue painter's tape going round the sides and the bottom, so the thickness is:
glass thickness + ( 2 * tape thickness) If you don't use tape, or if you apply tape differently, the clips might not work perfectly for you.

Print at 0.2mm layers.  
I made mine in black PLA.  
I suggest printing 4 of them so that, should something happen to the pair you currently use, you have a backup to hold the glass while you print another pair (which will become your backup), and so on...

author: alex80it

description.text:
One step closer to the world. The virtuous cycle of innovation is a very good thing. I have received much support and ideas from syvwlch http://www.thingiverse.com/syvwlch I have been inspired by the printable clock, and his recent curvy work. Doing free form solids in OpenScad has been a challenging endeavor. There is some math involved, and a lot of head scratching. This thing is one step closer to providing Bezier surfaces that are actually printable. In the last iteration, I had the Bezier surface rendering, but it was a pure graphic construct, which was not printable. Now that I've discovered fire (polyhedron), I have been able to get one step closer to making the thing actually solid. In this particular case, you can now specify the thickness of your surface, and the routine will 'do the needful'. I haven't done any experimentation with polyhedra and CSG commands in OpenScad, so I don't know what happens when you cut out a cylinder from the thing, for example. but, again, one step closer. The way this thing is done is to use the normals at each vertex, and project 'inward' in the opposite direction for the length of 'thickness' to get a new set of vertices. This new set represents a triangle which is inward from the 'outer' surface. From there, it's a matter of constructing a new surface, and the interjoining quads to seal the edges. The approach is right for a triangle in isolation, but as can be seen from the image, leaves a lot of gaps. The final solution there is to actually calculate a new surface inward from the original control points, and calculate the appropriate points between the surfaces directly. But, that will be the final step. Blah, blah, blah At any rate, solid Bezier surfaces are one step closer. UPDATE: Added a .stl file: bezier_surface_polyhedra1
This file represents using the polyhedron technique to its fullest. So, it shows that you can in fact generate manifold solids from closed polyhedra.

1) Load up the test_bezier.scad file
2) Play with parameters (like number of steps)
3) Press 'F5'
4) Play with pretty picture
5) Rejoice!

comments.text: I've added a .stl file here that demonstrates surfaces can be generated from the polyhedra making up the Bezier surface.  In this particular case, I have actually made modifications to the test_bezier.scad file, which I have yet to publish.  There are no cracks or gaps in the surface, and it can participate fully in CSG operations.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: So basically you have implemented linear_extrude() that actually works (imho the way it should work in openscad and the way it does work in rapcad) but you are also trying to implement an inset() module. is it possible that you could implement inset in such a way that it will work with all primitives?
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Yes, the current form is essentially a linear_extrude for surfaces.  It's not the best way of dealing with curves though.  Think of when you have a surface with an overhang, especially if it hangs over itself.  Things just won't be 'correct'.  But, for a great many shapes, this particular method will be worthwhile.
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: So thinking about it there are two types of inset, prehaps this one would be called inset_extrude and can be used to make 3d forms from sufaces such as yours.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: It's beginning to sound like the professional CAD programs out there.  There's a certain amount that can be done with the limitations of OpenScad.  At the very least, we now understand how to do a linear_extrude on a Bezier surface.  The same technique can be applied to any surface that can be tesselated.  The thing can be rotated as well, if that's interesting.
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: Dynamic arrays is not something that I had considered when developing rapcad, RapCAD does support real assign operators though so maybe you can append to an existing array that way? I would need to test it.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: I think it would be awesome if you did built in Bezier surface support.  Doing at least as much as I have done here is fairly straight forward.  The blend functions are absolutely trivial, and so is figuring out quads along the curves.  the rest is just placing a quad of the right thickness into the right place.  OpenScad isn't the most powerful and flexible language in the world, so if it can be done in OpenScad, it can probably be done anywhere.
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: You could also union() convex hulls around spheres with the desired thickness (diameter) at the bezier points. Would be horribly slow, though.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: I think the problem could better be solved by adding a BezierSurface Module the the application itself, its sufficiently non-trival and broadly useful. It seems as though you have gone though terrible pains to coax openscad into achieving what you desire.
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: That RapCad looks very interesting as well.  It would be great if it could do a true surface with thickness.  Then I could model, and print, the two halves of my mouse, print them out, and get a new mouse case.
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: I have played with the flat bottom approach.  That might be good in some cases.
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: Hello. This is great, the maths is sound and the functionality is getting there. However, I think the implementation is a bit wrong.
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: Yep, that's why it's still version 0.9
comments.author: GilesBathgate

comments.text: I faced the same question with the extrude-transform work. I don't know of a way to do this in OpenSCAD.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: the real ultimate solution for me will be to use extruded polygon (triangles).  They are solid, and they'll be manifold, and CSG-able.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Well, the polyhedrons, properly defined, work well for me for generating STLs and Skeinforge is prefectly happy to slice them. If you want to really optimize them, a quick trip to netfabb will do fine but is not strictly necessary.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Here you go, nice clean difference CSG on a pile of polyhedrons, done in a minute and exported as a 200kB STL file. :-)
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: I don't like to just extrude the triangles because that is less flexible than a properly defined polyhderon. You can twist the extrusion, but you can't tilt the second face, resize it, etc...
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: In this version 0.9, you calculate the normals of the points of a quad by using the other quad points. That way, the normals of two adjacent quads are different and the patches don't line up nicely.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Yes, normals at the curve points.  And use those to calculate the points for the 'inner' quad, then build a polyhedron from there.
comments.author: Proton

comments.text: great work here! keep it up!
comments.author: EFFALO

comments.text: Getting close! :-)
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: If there was a way to have a parameter or set of parameters generate the two bezier curves offset by the thickness from the same function(s), you could generate the two set of vertices easily, and they would always match up for both surfaces. That's how I do it with the screw thread modules.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: It might be a simple as changing the weights for the control points for the two surfaces... perhaps?
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: The way I did it for the triangles was to just calculate the normals at each of the vertices, and use that to drive the offsets.
comments.author: syvwlch

remixed_from.author: schlem
remixed_from.title: terraPin, a 120 Film Pinhole Photography System

description.text:
Kaiju (怪獣) is a Japanese word that literally translates to "monster," and is used to refer to a genre of tokusatsu (special effects-based) entertainment. Kaiju films usually showcase monsters of any form, usually attacking a major Japanese city or engaging another (or multiple) monster(s) in battle. I grew up watching Japanese Kaiju movies on TV every Sunday afternoon on channel 11's Sci-Fi Theatre. Gamera, a rocket-powered flying turtle beast, was and remains my favorite Kaiju. I hope it is obvious that the terraPin Kaiju is a giant mutant pinhole, a pinhole Gamera! 120 film!
6 X 18 cm frame!
116.5 degrees!
86mm concentric film plane!
Designed for 0.40mm pinhole!
f/215! See terraPin High-Strength Winder (1/4" shaft) for additional winder/knob options! Use exposure calculations for the PINH5AD!
Now with exposure calculations with Reciprocity Failure for common B&W films; see:
B&W_Pinhole_Exposure_Durations_Kaiju_f215.pdf Featured on the Adafruit 3D Hangout for 7/2/15! I typically embelish my pinhole cameras with knurling to add interesting visual and tactile textures. Unfortunately, the mutant size of the Kaiju required so many thousands of extra polygons that they constituted a persistant source of non-manifold errors and rendering ambiguity. I hope to further develop the Kaiju to include the knurling in the future and I cite the "Knurled Surface Library v2" by aubenc as recognition of his contributions to my camera design.

CLICK HERE for the latest photographs I have made with the various terraPin cameras.
I have created a 3D Printed Cameras group on Flickr
The mission is to share and promote open source cameras and related parts, created with CAD applications and 3D printing. Please join and post content! NOTE
The sample photos are WIDE (6X18). Unless you view them full screen, they will be severly cropped. Normally, my local film lab scans my film, but 6 X 18 is too big for their NORITSU scanner. All scans shown are my ham-fisted work and may deviate from original exposures in various ways. I vow to do better.
NOW AVAILABLE 6X18 sanning adapter for the Epson V500!

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

The terraPin Kaiju is a comparatively simple camera. Assembly should be intuitive, but I plan to add some exploded parts diagrams in the near future for clarification. Vitamins:
0.40mm pinhole
4 x panhead M3 bolts 10mm length
2 x M3 nuts
1/4-20 flanged nut for tripod mount
Finishing tools like files
Flat black paint for inside (minimize reflections)
Translucent red plastic for indexing window
Super Glue 3D printed parts always required some finishing for precise fit. Pay particular attention to the winder baffles, the shutter, the outside joint of the top frame, and the sliding index cover plate. This camera uses counter-sunk bolts to hold the top frame and shutter assembly in place. I used a M3 tap for the bolts that hold the top frame (middle two holes). The M3 nuts slide into the nut traps to hold the lid on - enlarge these (outer two) holes with a 1/8" drill bit and clear debris from nut traps. Refer to the lid if unclear which holes do what. I don't glue my knob and winder assemblies. They can break (never done it, but possible), and replacement is easier if you just press fit everything together. The terraPin Kaiju relies on parts from prior terraPin designs, and individual parts can be downloaded from source Things (see sources) should the need arise for a single part. The tall piece with the diamond shaped hole through it is the latest version of a 120 film clip. The take up roll (the one you wind) is sometimes prone to unwinding a bit during unloading. The clip slides into the spool cavity during loading and prevents light leaks during unloading. Click here for the original design from the P6*6
You will find a document in the "Thing Files" section for download that goes into greater detail. I have included some version of this part with all of my 120 film pinhole cameras. The film winds on the left and the frame is indexed at frames 1, 3, 5, and 7 for 4 exposures per roll of 120 film. The film clip can prevent your roll of film from unspooling during unloading and being ruined by light leaks into the roll of film. A word about winding: DO NOT TRY TO PULL THE FILM with the uptake knob. Give a bit of slack with the supply knob, take up slack with uptake knob, repeat until desired frame number is in the window. Horsing the film can cause it to fold inside the arc, necessitating a PITA teardown and possible loss of a roll of film. Film is precious - be methodical! As always, I am at your service if you have questions - please post in the comments section for everyone to see!
Thanks!
-schlem

comments.author: peterpinhole

comments.text:
Me and my friend made one (well, she's the one with the 3D printing experience, I just mostly tagged along tbh) and the photos from the first roll look brilliant! However, the second roll jammed up totally after the first photo, and the third roll of film after the third photo. The second roll was a total loss, the third I managed to safe in the dark room. Both the second and third rolls were Lomography films (Redscale 100 and Redscale 50-200), the first Rollei (RPX25), could the jamming be caused by the backing paper Lomography uses? Any experience with these films?
Anyhoo, long story short: great camera, great photos (I'll be posting some soon-ish) but I'm still trying to figure out why films jam all the time.
comments.author: LeoLensen

comments.text: I haven't used that film, but if I had to guess, it may have been winding technique.  Because of the curved film "plane", there is a lot of friction in the camera when advancing the film.  I have found that, in order to avoid folding the film inside the camera, the "supply" spool must be slackened BEFORE the "takeup" spool is advanced. This is done in a back-and-forth manner: slack, wind, slack, wind...   If that is already your technique, I must blame the Lomo film. Their cameras are mostly junk, it wouldn't surprise me that their film might be dodgy too.
comments.author: LeoLensen

comments.text: Well, I did the giving slack-before-advancing thing with the third roll (the second roll I just tried to advance the film from left to right as you do with most cameras but not this one, that was the end of the second roll). So maybe it's the backing paper, I don't know. I don't know why people knock Lomography so much, I've hardly ever had any problems with their cameras or film... Anyhoo, I uploaded the first photo I took with this camera to my tumblr: http://leolensenphotography.tumblr.com/post/137688197553/pinhole-photo-made-with-the-terrapin-kajiu-6x18
comments.author: schlem

comments.text: Without seeing how the film jammed, anything I say is a guess. It is a little fiddly to load the Kaiju. If the film isn't in quite the right place or has a wrinkle in it, it is at risk for folding and jamming. As to Lomography, I believe they sell film and cameras on the promise of "happy accidents" from unreliable tools and media. If all you know is a smartphone camera, it can be a compelling creative experience. Lomo sells a LOT of film and that's good, but I like a repeatable workflow and that starts with quality film. Redscale films have been flipped to shoot the back of the emulsion, and that would reverse the film's natural curl, and possibly how the film lies in the camera. I get great results with Kodak, Fuji, Ilford, and and Rollei film stocks. I avoid Lomo films primarily because the film's origin and, more importantly, reciprocity failure behavior is a mystery.
comments.author: LeoLensen

author: ozanbdr

description.text: A knob for the joystick of our Laos Laser cutter. It is for the joystick switch (rs article number 516-316) A file for the cover is also included.

This Nintendo Nes style knob works well for the joystick switch. We printed them on an Ultimaker in normal and high quality, both came out ok. I also included a cover for the Laos panel so the pcb and switch are better protected. You can cut the cover with your lasercutter. Make sure there is enough space between the pcb and the cover otherwise the joystick and knobs cannot move enough. We used 10mm distanceholders. I have included distanceholders in the cover file. More about Laos open source lasercutter can be found here: http://redmine.laoslaser.org/projects/laos/wiki/LAOS_I2C_Panel_v04

comments.text: Nice! Does such a big knob work okay with such a small joystick?
comments.author: peteruithoven

comments.text: Thanks Peter! we didn't do an endurance test yet but it works pretty good. The cover is also keeping the knob in place somewhat so you cannot force the joystick beyond its limits.
comments.author: peteruithoven

I like where ianjohnson is going with his winder project but it is built around using his spool design and I have tons of the 50mm hub spools laying around. (The same type that MBI sells) So I made a solution to print everything needed. You just need 3 608 bearings and some threaded rod and nuts. The gear is compatible with ianjohnson winder. The gear has a bearing on both ends and the cap has a bearing. The knob which is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3723 has been shorten so the nut sticks out the bottom and won't rub the cap while it spins.Making the whole assembly spin while clamping the spool in the holder. Easy on - easy off.

comments.text: A Kickstarter project for this would sell. Just a thought. Our makerspace would buy this if it came in a complete kit.
comments.author: RSkarl

comments.text: I want to work it into a kit, which would involve a custom PCB.  I'm not that interested in running a Kickstarter though, I would rather have everything ready before taking money.  Maybe start off with a small run to finance larger orders.
comments.author: RSkarl

comments.text: I agree it would make a great kickstarter project however it's not my project it ianjohnson's. He has been doing all the work and I'm just trailing behind and modifying his stuff to fit my needs. If ianjohnson like anything I'm doing and he wants to roll it into his project he is more than welcome.
comments.author: RSkarl

comments.text: One thing you would need to add on the gear is a hole for a magnet so the hall sensor can count the rotations.  It would be at a radius of 37.5mm from the center of the rod.
comments.author: ianjohnson

description.text: I was looking for one of these here and couldn't find one, so made my own. It came out a bit large, so I included a smaller version. It should be beefy enough to hold up to a bit of abuse. I also included a compatible hook for your cabinet. Enjoy!
With a thing like this I like to print with 100% infill. The hook can be mounted with double-sided tape, silicone, or hot glue.

comments.text:
Not sure if I'm replying in the correct comment area. I'm new to this hobby, and the iPhone app isn't so great. I made both this pick and the other pick style by this creator, I like the style of both. I attempted both multiple times but was unsuccessful. During each attempt I encountered the same issue; the teeth would curl up and block the extruder resulting as you see in the photos I posted in the I made section. Like I said though Im very new to this hobby so I'm not sure if the settings I used were correct or not. I'm using the Divinci jr. My first goes at them used the default settings. For my second attempts I slowed the speed down and increased the layer thickness. Same results during each attempt. I would like to make two suggestions. One, I think decreasing the number of teeth, and rounding the edges of each. And second the combs seem very thin, probably won't work for people with 3c through 4c hair types, so a bit thicker would be great.
Thanks
comments.author: Rei82

comments.text: it's probably just a bed adhesion issue try using a squirt of hairspray on the bed before you print, it will most likely take care of the curling.
comments.author: Rei82

title: Rostock Max V2 Case Cooling Fan Mount - 80mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My Rostock Max V2 steppers were running hotter than I would like.  I had a machine crash on a hot day that was likely caused by an overly hot stepper driver on the motherboard.  I decided cooler is better than hotter so I designed this fan mount to be added to the side of the case where the access panels normally would be.  
The design is made to place the fan inside at an angle so that it blows toward the motherboard, past the X axis stepper.  A mirrored version of this would fit the other side for twice the cooling but is probably overkill.  I plan on also adding a grill piece to allow flow-through cooling around both steppers with just one fan.  The idea would be that the air would flow around the electronics and then out the other side.  To force this airflow you would really need to block or restrict the vent holes in the bottom to force the air to move through, past the pieces that generate heat.  
Printed and installed!  6/14/15 - It fits nicely and does a nice job of providing additional airflow to the motherboard and steppers.  I ran my first 4+ hour print yesterday with no mishaps this time.

comments.text: This was designed in inches.  You'll need to set your CAD import to inches or scale at 25.4.
comments.author: corski67

comments.text: Thanks for your reply, I tried printing this and although the sizes of the plate were correct, I found that the duct doesn't fit a standard 80mm PC case fan - it's too small. I've decided to make my own as a bit of a learning exercise.

Thanks for posting this. I would like to use your design but when I try to print it, the dimensions are tiny. eg 7mm in width!

author: ozanbdr

description.text:
I made this dril chuck key holder for my drill press.
A protection shield with a 15x15mm aluminium post, which i don't use (even couldn't my first drilling job because thing was in the way..)
I decided to make a drill chuck key holder that could be clamped instead. You can use it as is, or insert 1 or 2 magnets with a 10mm diameter with a little screw to let the key click in its place. Work beautifully! I also made a universal version you could mount virtually anywhere

clamp size is exactly 15x15mm.
I ended up printing it at 110% for a tiny better fit

Two reasons for the creation of this thing :
I was concerned about the bending some have experienced with the MK8 original extruder bracket. It was not happening for me (as of yet) but better be prepared for it ...
I wanted a quick & easy access to the nozzle and extruder part, and the bracket was getting in the way.
Note : ABS is strongly recommanded.

You may wonder why there are 2 stl files for this thing, and that's because I ran into a quite unexpected problem.
You're supposed to print extruder_mount_plate_A : it's supposed to be the one with the correct measurements for every mounting holes, but for some reason, when I printed it, the holes were totally off by 4 or 5mm. Strange thing is : knowing that, I ran some calibration process but all return good !
That's why I made extruder_mount_plate_B. This one is supposed to be smaller and normally can't fit but for me ... it does the trick.
So either I have some strange calibration problem going on, either my measurements were off, take your guess ;)

comments.text:
In this photo I'm using the original x-carriage which comes with my i3 Prusa Pro B. You could also use this one I made :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1029828 but you will need 4 x LME8UU in stead of the two LME8LUU.
comments.author: mediaklan

comments.text: Should rework that for LME8LUU! I cant find a mounting plate to mount this properly
comments.author: mediaklan

comments.text:
Not possible with this carriage : the two LME8LUU prevents to be able to use the Rework extruder mounting holes (which is why I switch to 4xLME8UU in the first place), which was the whole point of the thing. You should search for the original x-carriage for the geeetech i3 pro B here (I've seen it here some time ago) or in the geeetech forums.
Here's one : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1072981
comments.author: Clwebb

comments.text: Ew ill pass on that one! Ugh I cant find a good X carriage or mount to use at all!
comments.author: mediaklan

comments.text: I have no idea what you're looking for then. Maybe it's time to start making one yourself. Good luck.
comments.author: Clwebb

title: Genie Series II Garage Door Button

description.text:
Replacement buttons for the standard wall-mount control button for Genie Series II garage door openers.  
Sizing it to fit better, and fixing the holes.  
Version 3 needs the tabs shortened and button faces tapered a bit more.  
Attempt 4 was a flop.  
Attempt 5 shortened the tabs and hollowed the buttons.  
Need to print and test.  
To Do Once Sizing Is Correct: Hollow out the undersides of the buttons and print in glow-in-the-dark to allow the LED to shine through. Add the lightbulb and up/down designs.
ABS, 235C, 75D bed, 0.2 layer height, 20% infill

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount for Printrbot Simple Metal (1403) with Heated Bed

description.text: A mounting bracket to attach a RPi camera to the right front corner of a Printrbot Simple Metal  with heated bed.

No hardware is required. The camera mount is held snugly in place by two angled clips that slide under the right printer-bed wing. Use with tiltArm.stl, caseFront.stl and caseBack.stl from Jerware (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:442063) I found 0.2-mm layer height with 100% fill to work really well. In fact, the 100% fill makes the mount very strong and allows the clips to bend without breaking. I was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:442063 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:671954, but I built this mount from scratch because I built several others (including the two linked to above) and none fit my bed very well and/or broke when I tried to attach them. I thought the slightly flexible two-clip approach would work better than a slot that needed to have perfect dimensions to fit. It does work pretty well. Because the two clips are not attached at the corner each can articulate independently without putting any stress on the other. I don't know if this will fit the Printrbot Simple Metal without the heated bed but if somebody tries it leave a comment to let me know how it turns out. I think the wings on the non-heated bed are slightly thinner so the clips my have to be pulled in a bit to get a snug fit. Fillets have been applied to all corners subjected to stress to prevent stress concentration. Also, the pegs that fit into the hole on Jerware's tiltArm.stl have been narrowed along one dimension so they are easier to insert. Sometimes a round hole works better with an oval peg.

title: Prop Blade Guard for Estes Proto X FPV Variant

description.text:
This is a prop guard for the FPV Proto X. I noticed there were models on here for the Proto X, but the FPV variant is much larger.  
Printed on a Stratasys Dimension, the "TIGHT" version worked well.   
Printed on a Makerbot 2X, the "TIGHT" version needed LOTS of filing and sanding. I suggest using the standard version if you have a hobby level FDM printer.   
This would also work great if laser cut from thin polyethylene, delrin, or polcarbonate, which is why I included the DXF file.  
If you want to play with the geometry, download the Solidworks or STEP file.

title: improved DC Fan holder for Thing-O-Matic Z stepper

description.text:
I like the DC Fan holder.
Transporting my Thing-O-Matic often I choose a very wide and long fan instead,
so it would never break of. (40x50 instead of 40x40 and 32mm thick with 2 fans and 2 motors)
Mine also uses a very strange bolt-size of M3.5 .
This required a redesign.
I am using 2 flat pieces on either end of the fan
instead of housing this large thing inside the DC fan holder.
My clamp-arm is not parallel to the wood but starting at 4mm and ending at 5.
This way it will clamp more securely and with more force. To still attach it easily I tapered the arm by 2mm
(and the bolt holes by my usual 1mm). The arm is also not as long as the fan.
With the fan 10mm wider, the arm would get in the way of the Z-endstop.
Thus it ends 15mm short of the back wall. blog post: http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/05/thing-o-matic-cooling-z-stepper.html

comments.text: Does your Z-Stepper get very hot? Mine was getting up to about 80C before I calibrated the driver, it's down to about 50C during builds now.
comments.author: RobertHunt

comments.text: Ok, I found that the person who helped me assemble the TOM made a mistake and my stepper was running in REF=2.x V instead of 0.615V .
comments.author: RobertHunt

comments.text: Yes it it getting hot and I did calibrate it as the wiki says.
comments.author: RobertHunt

author: MarcusWolschon

description.text:
"Clouds of dark smoke hung over the freshly blasted mine entrance. In the stygian darkness beyond, a faint glimmer could be seen, hovering motes without tell of depth. Soon a flutter could be heard, soft at first, then rising to a cacophonous flurry, the once-dim motes now given form. They poured from that empty place, taking the worst aspects of bats, jellyfish, and ticks, their luminescent skin betraying the pulsing shapes of their strange, internal biology. Screeching in a sound born beyond the stars, they tore, stung, and bit until there were none left to give witness save the phantom eyes of the automated surveillance footage."  
Felt like trying my hand at some random alien creatures and was pretty happy with these guys. They're designed in 15mm scale, though they could really be used with any range.
Printed in halves and assembled with superglue. Painted with model acrylics.

comments.text: I made one of these and it is a fantastic design.  Prints out great!

comments.text:
Hi,
I put a tape on the area that i planned to cut and then I used a jigsaw with a fine toothed saw blade to cut it. Important! Cut with slow speed to avoid the saw blade to get warm which may melt the acrylic material. Use patience and it will pay you back with a good result. I used the Handle Piece as a template to bore the three holes. Make a paper template for the upper and lower cover and it will help you to define the outfit for these parts. Sorry, no drawings from me but you are free to remix it.

description.text:
These hooks were designed for hanging a 1 x 1/2m framed mirror on a door.  There are 4 variations of the hook, one for each corner of the mirror.  The hooks screw to the back of the plastic mirror frame, and are slotted to capture the heads of mounting screws in the door.  
The doors I am hanging on are hollow and the mounting screws only pierce the outer timber skin.  Even so, 4 screws seem to be adequately strong to support the mirror.
The brackets were printed on a Replicator with ABS at 25% infill, 1 extra shell, no raft or support required.
